I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) in implementing its Strategic Plan for Rural Vitalization, 2018–2022.1 The TA will 
support sustainable agriculture production and waste management by (i) developing green 
agriculture production models for grain-producing areas of Heilongjiang and Shandong provinces 
experiencing soil and land degradation, (ii) proposing new models for the effective treatment and 
management of rural and agriculture organic waste in key grain producing areas, and (iii) 
supporting Qinghai Province in implementing the Strategic Plan for Rural Vitalization, 2018–2022. 
These outputs will generate new knowledge and strategies to support rural vitalization and 
sustainable agriculture development in the PRC. 
 
2.  The Government of the PRC requested TA from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for 
Agriculture Green Production and Waste Management.2 The TA is included in ADB’s country 
operations business plan, 2019–2021 for the PRC.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The PRC has seen unprecedented economic growth from 1978 to 2017, lifting millions out 
of poverty and improving human well-being and quality of life across the country.4 However, this 
impressive economic performance has had adverse environmental consequences that threaten 
the livelihood and health of the population in rural areas and their neighboring urban centers. Soil 
contamination and land degradation, water pollution, and poor resource management have 
become widespread and are pressing concerns for national and local governments. Adding to 
these environmental pressures, the impacts of climate change, including irregular climate patterns 
and  extreme  weather  events,  have  already  severely  impacted  agriculture  and  undermined 
economic progress, threatening the country’s food and water security. 
 
4.  There is a need to transform agriculture production and address the ecological challenges 
the PRC faces by promoting environmental protection, waste management, and sustainable 
agriculture development. The core problem of unsustainable agriculture production and lack of 
ecological protection of land, water, and other natural resources has multifaceted causes and 
numerous effects. Excessive resource consumption, inefficient and unrestrained application of 
chemical pesticides and fertilizers on crops, and irrigation with untreated wastewater all contribute 
to the pollution of farmland and deterioration of the soil. Land degradation will only increase if the 
PRC’s soil continues to suffer from reduced fertility, erosion, changes in acidity, accumulation of 
plastic film residues, the effects of climate change, and damage from pollutants. 
 
5.  Pollution  and  environmental  degradation  because  of  the  improper  treatment  and 
management of rural and agriculture waste has also become an urgent concern. The rapid 
development of the PRC’s livestock industry, driven by population growth, market demand, and 
technological and policy support, has been accompanied by a large increase in waste production 
from intensive livestock and poultry farms. The improper treatment and use of much of this waste 
has had, and will continue to have, serious long-term ecological impacts.

6.  While many of these environmental and agriculture development challenges are national 
and provincial concerns, effectively implementing the Strategic Plan for Rural Vitalization, 2018–
2022 in provinces such as Qinghai will require a deeper exploration of the constraints to, and 
opportunities for, rural vitalization. Important questions requiring further investigation include: 
What  are  the  key  constraints  facing  the  rural  farm  and  nonfarm  sector?  What  are  the 
environmental protection challenges in Qinghai? How does the province promote rural–urban 
integration and cohesion? How can Qinghai foster a culture of innovation and modernization in 
the agriculture industry, develop agriculture value chains and link agribusinesses and local 
entrepreneurs  with  smallholder  farmers?  What  is  the  state  of  rural  service  delivery  and 
governance in Qinghai? Are there critical social and physical infrastructure gaps that need to be 
addressed, including lack of health, education, and financial services? Answers to these and other 
related questions will provide the first critical step in supporting an evidence-based, scientific, and 
sustainable approach to implementing the Strategic Plan for Rural Vitalization, 2018–2022 in 
Qinghai. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: sustainable agriculture development and 
ecological environment improved.5 The TA will have the following outcome: opportunities to 
modernize agriculture systems identified.6 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  The three outputs of the TA aim to address three distinct sets of challenges experienced 
by the PRC: they aim to understand how to (i) pivot toward green animal production and crop 
cultivation models; (ii) effectively treat, use, and manage rural organic waste; and (iii) effectively 
implement rural vitalization in the provinces. All three outputs will generate new knowledge and 
awareness on sustainable agriculture development and support the Strategic Plan for Rural 
Vitalization, 2018–2022 in the PRC. 
 
9.  Output 1: Knowledge of natural resource use and models for green agriculture 
production developed. This output will support the PRC in identifying improved models for green 
agriculture production in two key grain-producing areas experiencing soil and land degradation: 
Heilongjiang and Shandong provinces. Specifically, this output aims to (i) assess the state and 
usage of natural resources and animal and/or crop production systems in the two provinces; (ii) 
analyze policies influencing natural resource use, chemical fertilizer and/or pesticide application, 
and agriculture production systems overall; and assess the social dimensions of production 
systems; (iii) propose climate-friendly models for animal production and crop cultivation that 
incorporate food safety and quality issues; (iv) undertake a cost–benefit analysis of the new green 
production models relative to current practices; and (v) prepare policy recommendations for 
provincial and national governments on how to use natural resources more efficiently and balance 
agriculture production with environmental priorities. 
 
10.  Output 2: New models for the proper treatment, usage, and management of rural 
organic waste proposed. This output will assist the PRC in better understanding the current 
usage and management of crop straw residue in key grain-producing areas, and in identifying the

technologies and models required for the effective reuse of crop straw. This output aims to (i) 
undertake an assessment and situation analysis of crop straw usage and management; (ii) 
evaluate policies, incentive structures, and mechanisms that contribute to the lack of social capital 
for  efficient  resource  use  and  clean  energy  development;  (iii)  summarize  domestic  and 
international best practices and technologies for the effective reuse of crop straw; (iv) propose 
new models for the effective reuse of crop straw tailored to the PRC context; and identify the 
necessary financial, institutional, and market requirements to pursue these technologies; and (v) 
prepare policy recommendations and action plans for provincial and national governments on 
how to effectively use rural organic waste for agriculture and clean energy development purposes. 
 
11.  Output 3: Knowledge and understanding of key constraints to, and priorities for, 
rural vitalization in Qinghai Province generated. The PRC’s rural vitalization policy aims to 
modernize agriculture and ensure the sustainable development of rural areas. This output aims 
to support the Qinghai provincial government in pursuing the Strategic Plan for Rural Vitalization, 
2018–2022. Specifically, this output will (i) generate new knowledge on the key constraints to 
rural  vitalization  in  Qinghai  and  propose  recommendations  for  addressing  challenges  in 
agriculture modernization, environmental protection, rural–urban integration, rural infrastructure 
and service delivery, and governance and/or institutional challenges; and (ii) develop strategies 
and  technical  recommendations  on  how  to  promote  livable  ecological  villages  in  Qinghai, 
addressing issues such as solid waste and wastewater management. This output will include 
recommendations on how to improve coordination within provincial government agencies and 
between provincial and national agencies for the purposes of rural vitalization. 
 
12.  Lessons learned. Previous projects indicated that involving senior government officials, 
concerned government agencies, and local experts in TA work and inviting their input to draft 
reports and review workshops are important to ensure quality outputs that meet the needs of 
various agencies. Greater benefits can be gained from policy research if dissemination is planned 
more strategically and the findings and recommendations that may be relevant to other provinces 
in similar situations are highlighted. 
 
13.  Strategic fit. The TA will support the PRC in implementing its Strategic Plan for Rural 
Vitalization, 2018–2022, and promoting the sustainable development of agriculture and the 
ecological protection of vital natural resources. The design of this TA supports the ADB Strategy 
2030  operational  priorities  on  promoting  rural  development  and  food  security  and  on 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity, and the Operational Plan for Agriculture and 
Natural Resources: Promoting Sustainable Food Security in Asia and the Pacific in 2015–2020.7 
The TA is in line with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for the PRC and supports 
the government’s 13th Five-Year Plan, 2016–2020, which aims to promote environment-friendly 
rural development and the sustainable use of natural resources.8 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000, of which $900,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 2.

15.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of remuneration and travel 
expenses of counterpart staff; provision of available government data and studies for the TA 
consultants’ use; provision of meeting rooms, office facilities, and geographic information system 
maps; and other in-kind contributions. The Qinghai provincial government, through the Qinghai 
Provincial Development and Reform Commission, will also finance and administer $50,000, 
separate from ADB’s fund flow. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer and coordinate TA implementation through the East Asia Department 
and will work closely with counterparts. The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs and the 
Qinghai Provincial Finance Department are the executing agencies. Each TA output has an 
assigned implementing agency that will implement the associated activities. The implementing 
agencies will (i) provide project management support and carry out day-to-day TA activities, such 
as overseeing the TA consultants’ work; (ii) organize peer reviews and comments on consultants’ 
reports; (iii) organize TA review workshops and stakeholder meetings; and (iv) coordinate with 
provincial government agencies and private stakeholders for awareness-raising and capacity 
building activities. Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

and TA staff instructions using a simplified technical proposal and the quality- and cost-based 
selection method.9 The quality–cost ratio will be 90:10 because of the high technical complexity 
of the consulting assignment. Disbursement of the TA proceeds will follow ADB’s Technical

18.  Output 1 of the TA will require 17.5 person-months of national consulting services. ADB 
will  recruit  a  firm  to  provide  national  expertise,  consisting  of  an  agriculture/climate  smart 
agriculture specialist who will be the team leader; a soil and natural resources management 
specialist;  a  livestock,  biogas,  and  organic  waste  specialist;  a  financial  specialist;  and  an 
agriculture/natural resources economist. Output 2 of the TA will require 19.0 person-months of 
national consulting services. The recruited firm will provide a organic waste/crop straw usage 
specialist who will be the team leader, a renewable energy specialist, an environmental specialist, 
an agriculture economist and financial specialist, and an institutional and policy specialist. Output 
3 of the TA will require 17.0 person-months of national consulting services. The recruited firm will 
provide an institutional and policy specialist who will be the team leader, a waste management 
specialist, and an agriculture/natural resources economist. The selected firm will also provide 2.0 
person-months of national consulting services from a TA coordinator, who will handle the overall 
TA management and ensure collaboration among the three outputs. Resource persons may be 
recruited  for  each  output  to  review  the  consultants’  outputs  and  share  knowledge  during 
workshops following ADB’s guidelines on recruiting and administering resource persons. 
 
19.  ADB’s procurement. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended 
from time to time).10

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Knowledge of natural resource use and models for green agriculture production developed 
1.1 Undertake assessment of unsustainable agriculture practices, policies, and animal and/or crop 
production systems that contribute to land and soil deterioration in Heilongjiang and Shandong 
provinces by month 7. 
1.2 Propose improved green production models for animal production and crop cultivation for Heilongjiang 
and Shandong provinces, including implementation guidelines, by month 12. 
1.3 Summarize domestic and international best practices for green agriculture production by month 14. 
1.4 Prepare policy recommendations for provincial and national governments on how to use natural 
resources more efficiently and balance agriculture production with environment priorities by month 20.  
1.5 Conduct TA inception mission by month 5, interim review mission by month 12, and final review 
mission by month 20.  
1.6 Disseminate knowledge products and hold knowledge-sharing workshop during TA implementation. 
 
2.  New models for the proper treatment, usage, and management of rural organic waste 
proposed 
2.1 Conduct an assessment of agriculture waste use and management with a focus on crop straw, 
highlighting practices, policies, and incentives contributing to the problem, by month 8. 
2.2 Summarize domestic and international best practices and technologies for the effective reuse of rural 
organic waste (crop straw) by month 12. 
2.3 Propose new models and strategies for the effective reuse of crop straw, adapted to the PRC context, 
including requirements to pursue these technologies, by month 14. 
2.4 Develop policy recommendations and action plans for improved use of crop straw for agriculture and 
clean energy development purposes by month 20.

Qinghai Province generated 
3.1 Prepare a research and policy report identifying primary constraints to the implementation of rural 
vitalization in Qinghai, examining topics such as agriculture modernization, environmental protection,

3.3 Conduct TA inception mission by month 5, interim review mission by month 12, and final review 
mission by month 20. 
3.4 Conduct knowledge-exchange and capacity building activities by month 20.
